intro: Mentha gentiliformis, commonly known as the meadow mint, is a perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are small, tubular, and clustered in whorls, producing a faintly aromatic scent. Mentha gentiliformis is often found in moist meadows and along stream banks, where it thrives in sunny to partially shaded conditions.
